prompt:
I need help. I'm not sure what's going on with me, but it's driving me crazy. After looking through the web, I found a Dr. Michael Szozas, who is a renowned psychiatrist and counselor.  Apparently he specializes in unusual cases. I'm not sure if my situation is unusual or not, and I'm not sure how to determine that, so I emailed him anyway.
Dr. Szozas was so nice, and he sounded so smart when he responded. He recommended at least an initial consultation. An appointment was made for Monday at 9am.
I'm nervous when I come up to his office; the entrance is a solid wooden door, and I reach out to knock. Rap rap rap. His voice comes, well-modulated and educated, "Come on in!"
I step into his office, and my eyes cast about; the lights are set to a soothing dim level, his walls are filled with books. I am tempted to read the titles, but I mustn't be rude, oh no. So I look at the man that is sitting behind his desk.
The first thing that strikes me is Dr. Szozas' warm, radiant grin -- with dimples! -- that told me that everything was going to be OK. Then these kind hazel eyes twinkling at me from behind a pair of wire-frame glasses. He rises up, and whoa, he's a tall man with a slender lanky frame that causes me to look up a bit at him. He wears a comfortable looking cardigan, and he has a pair of slacks, ending in some loafers. Dr. Szozas walks towards me, and takes my hand in his -- I immediately notice how large and warm his hand is, his skin soft as it wraps around my fingers, "I'm glad to see you," he says, and he seems to mean it. One could fall in love with someone like him so quickly, with his apparent sincerity and kindness.
"Please, take a seat on the couch, make yourself comfortable.  State for the record your full name, and why you're here," he suggests, and he ambles over to sit in a comfortable armchair.  His hazel eyes fixate upon me, drinking and studying every detail of me as he waits for my response.
I hesitate, and sit down on the couch, and I respond, "
result:
My name is Mary Anne Smith." My mouth feels dry, and I feel a little anxious, but I continue, "And I've been experiencing some... uhm..." I pause again, trying to find the right words, "...some weird things recently."
He smiles broadly, "Go ahead, tell me what's happening."
I begin telling him about the strange dreams I have had, which seem to be connected to this web site. I describe seeing images and videos related to the occult, and even reading some disturbing material. I mention that I am having trouble sleeping, that I am feeling agitated most days, and that I am losing weight because I don't eat much.   "It sounds to me like something may be wrong with your brain chemistry. Do you drink alcohol?"
"No!" I answer emphatically, "But I do use marijuana occasionally."
Dr. Szozas nods knowingly, "That can cause similar symptoms, though not necessarily."
I shrug, "So what should I do? Should I just go back to using weed?"
"You might want to try cutting back or stopping entirely for a while. See if that helps."
"Okay, I will. Thank you very much!"
We chat a bit more about the medical issues that I am facing, and then we talk about the therapy sessions that I am planning to attend. He gives me a few ideas about the types of therapies that would be helpful for me, and I thank him profusely.
As I get up to leave, I ask him one last thing:
"What is the strangest case that you ever treated?"
He ponders that question for a moment, and then responds, "Well, there was a woman who was convinced that her husband was a vampire. She was convinced that he was feeding off of her blood supply, and she was afraid to let anyone else touch her during sex. I got the impression that it bothered her quite a bit

Apparently he specializes in unusual cases. I'm not sure if my situation is unusual or not, and I'm not sure how to determine that, so I emailed him anyway.
Dr. Szozas was so nice, and he sounded so smart when he responded. He recommended at least an initial consultation. An appointment was made for Monday at 9am.
I'm nervous when I come up to his office; the entrance is a solid wooden door, and I reach out to knock. Rap rap rap. His voice comes, well-modulated and educated, "Come on in!"
I step into his office, and my eyes cast about; the lights are set to a soothing dim level, his walls are filled with books. I am tempted to read the titles, but I mustn't be rude, oh no. So I look at the man that is sitting behind his desk.
The first thing that strikes me is Dr. Szozas' warm, radiant grin -- with dimples! -- that told me that everything was going to be OK. Then these kind hazel eyes twinkling at me from behind a pair of wire-frame glasses. He rises up, and whoa, he's a tall man with a slender lanky frame that causes me to look up a bit at him. He wears a comfortable looking cardigan, and he has a pair of slacks, ending in some loafers. Dr. Szozas walks towards me, and takes my hand in his -- I immediately notice how large and warm his hand is, his skin soft as it wraps around my fingers, "I'm glad to see you," he says, and he seems to mean it. One could fall in love with someone like him so quickly, with his apparent sincerity and kindness.
"Please, take a seat on the couch, make yourself comfortable.  State for the record your full name, and why you're here," he suggests, and he ambles over to sit in a comfortable armchair.  His hazel eyes fixate upon me, drinking and studying every detail of me as he waits for my response.
I hesitate, and sit down on the couch, and I respond, "
result:
My name is Rosemary." My face flushes red at saying this aloud. It feels strange to give my real name to another person. The doctor nods encouragingly, and continues, "And why did you decide to seek help?"
"Well...it started one day last week, after I had been working all night..." I explain. I try to keep eye contact with him while telling him what happened. But I feel myself getting more nervous by the moment.
He looks concerned, "Did something happen? What exactly happened?"
I pause again, feeling embarrassed at having shared such personal information with another human being. I can tell that he wants to help me, but I don't know if I want to share any further details. I just nod slightly.
Dr. Szozas leans forward, his elbows resting on his knees, and places his hands together, "It's alright, please continue. Tell me everything that happened."
So I do, trying not to stutter or fumble too much. When I finish, he sits back and ponders for a few moments before speaking, "You've experienced intrusive thoughts related to the web site you visited?"
"Yes," I reply softly, with shame creeping up my cheeks.
"What sort of things have you seen?" he asks gently.
"Um, well, there are lots of different images, sometimes I get flashes of people who are dying, or maybe they're being tortured, I'm not sure. Sometimes I think I'm seeing their brains being sliced open, or that they're being dissected, I'm really freaked out about that. And then there are the dreams that I'm dreaming about the same thing, but I'm awake, I'm aware, but I'm still asleep, and I'm watching the brain surgeon cut into the body of the woman who is lying dead in front of me. I'm scared to wake up because I'm afraid that I'll be that corpse.

I hesitate, and sit down on the couch, and I respond, "
result:
My name is Kaitlyn Taylor." My head turns away from him, embarrassed by this simple answer, yet I continue. "Well... I guess 'Kaitlyn' isn't really enough. I've always been called that, but I don't feel right using that name anymore. It just doesn't seem right any more. Maybe because I have changed so much since then..."
He nods sympathetically, "Go ahead, tell me what happened."
So I do. I describe all the changes I went through, and the things that happened to me. I talk about the horrible experiences, the bad dreams, and the loss of control. I explain how I started feeling different, almost like there were two people inside me: one being who was trying to live her life normally, while another part wanted nothing else than to hurt everyone she came across. And I talked about the change in my body, and the terrible transformation that had occurred. The parts of myself that I didn't know existed, the ones that felt wrong.
When I finished talking, Dr. Szozas sat quietly, contemplating something. When he spoke again, his voice sounded softer, less formal. "Do you remember anything before the changes?"
"No, not really," I responded honestly. I was hoping that the doctor would ask questions about the time leading up to the events I described; perhaps he'd be able to shed some light on what was happening to me?
Dr. Szozas nodded, and took out a pen and a notebook from his desk drawer. He flipped open the cover and looked at me, "OK, let's start at the beginning. What day is today?"
"It's Monday, March 6th, 2011. Why are we starting at the beginning?" I asked, confused.
"Because I need to get a sense of where you are mentally, emotionally, to understand the issues that brought you to me," he replied.
I think back

"Samantha, I am a doctor, but I am also a counselor. You are here because I believe that we are going to be able to work together to improve your quality of life. I hate having to go to the bathroom, I dread the idea of cleaning it up afterwards, and I'm always afraid of making a mess. It makes me miserable to live there, and I often wish that I would just move somewhere else entirely.
Then one day I found out about the internet, and suddenly realized that I could escape all that unpleasantness if only I had a computer to use. So I got one, and I spent hours online reading articles, watching videos, and chatting with friends. But I still felt trapped, lonely, and unhappy. I couldn't concentrate, I was irritable and moody, I was anxious and depressed, I was angry at the world and at myself, I was sick to death of the constant barrage of sensory input that was assaulting me 24/7, I was bored and restless, I was tired of trying to be something I wasn't, I was frustrated at the fact that I was unable to do what I wanted to.

prompt:
I need help. I'm not sure what's going on with me, but it's driving me crazy. After looking through the web, I found a Dr. Michael Szozas, who is a renowned psychiatrist and counselor.  Apparently he specializes in unusual cases. I'm not sure if my situation is unusual or not, and I'm not sure how to determine that, so I emailed him anyway.
Dr. Szozas was so nice, and he sounded so smart when he responded. He recommended at least an initial consultation. An appointment was made for Monday at 9am.
I'm nervous when I come up to his office; the entrance is a solid wooden door, and I reach out to knock. Rap rap rap. His voice comes, well-modulated and educated, "Come on in!"
I step into his office, and my eyes cast about; the lights are set to a soothing dim level, his walls are filled with books. I am tempted to read the titles, but I mustn't be rude, oh no. So I look at the man that is sitting behind his desk.
The first thing that strikes me is Dr. Szozas' warm, radiant grin -- with dimples! -- that told me that everything was going to be OK. Then these kind hazel eyes twinkling at me from behind a pair of wire-frame glasses. He rises up, and whoa, he's a tall man with a slender lanky frame that causes me to look up a bit at him. He wears a comfortable looking cardigan, and he has a pair of slacks, ending in some loafers. Dr. Szozas walks towards me, and takes my hand in his -- I immediately notice how large and warm his hand is, his skin soft as it wraps around my fingers, "I'm glad to see you," he says, and he seems to mean it. One could fall in love with someone like him so quickly, with his apparent sincerity and kindness.
"Please, take a seat on the couch, make yourself comfortable.  State for the record your full name, and why you're here," he suggests, and he ambles over to sit in a comfortable armchair.  His hazel eyes fixate upon me, drinking and studying every detail of me as he waits for my response.
I hesitate, and sit down on the couch, and I respond, "
result:
My name is Samantha Anderson."  He nods, and then continues, "And what brings you here?"
"Well, I've been experiencing strange things recently, and they seem related somehow..." I begin.
"Strange things? What do you mean by 'strange things'?" asks Dr. Szozas, leaning forward slightly, "Have there been any changes in your life recently? Any stressors?"
"No...no real change, just weird stuff happening," I say slowly.
"What sort of weird stuff?" he presses further.
"Um, okay, let's start with the dreams, which have become more frequent lately. And also, uhm, odd feelings inside me. Like something is different than usual, or out of place. It's hard to describe," I admit.
Dr. Szozas sits back, pondering this new information, "Alright, tell me about the dreams. Do you remember them clearly? Are they vivid? Can you recall anything specific that happens during the dream?"
"Yes, yes, very clear. I can even write them down if you want," I offer eagerly.
"That would be helpful," he replies, "Do you ever feel anxious when you wake up after having one of those dreams? Or are you always calm when waking up?"
"Oh no, no, I get really nervous when I wake up. I don't know what to expect when I open my eyes. Sometimes I think I'm still dreaming, but I'm not sure anymore," I explain.
"How long does the anxiety last? Is it only when you awaken from the sleep, or when you are awake, too?"
"It lasts until I'm fully awake, but I'm not sure when that is exactly. I'm usually pretty tired when I go to bed, but sometimes I'm wide awake when I finally drift off to sleep. I try to stay asleep, but I often find myself

result:
My name is Heather, and I'm here because I've been having trouble sleeping."
He nods thoughtfully, and then asks, "How long have you had this problem?"
"Since Friday night. It started after dinner, and got progressively worse through Saturday, and now... Well, it's getting really bad. The last two nights were awful. I can't sleep more than four hours at a time. I just lie there tossing and turning until dawn breaks."
Dr. Szozas leans forward, elbows resting on his knees, hands clasped together, "And what do you think caused this difficulty?"
"Well, maybe stress? My husband died unexpectedly yesterday afternoon, and I guess it hit me pretty hard. But I don't know if that's all it is..."
"Have you ever experienced insomnia before?"
"No, never. And I haven't taken any drugs recently either. I wouldn't even touch Ambien or something like that."
Dr. Szozas smiles again, "So, we'll start with the basics: Have you done anything different lately? Anything unusual, perhaps?"
"Not really. I went grocery shopping today, and I spent most of the day doing housework. I watched a movie with my son on TV, but that was it. I didn't go anywhere special. Nothing out of the ordinary."
"What about sexual activity? Are you sexually active?"
"Yes, I am; I'm married to a wonderful man. We have a good sex life, and I enjoy making love with him. I was a little worried about that when I heard about his death, but I'm not sure if that was the cause of the insomnia, or if it was a coincidence. I'm still confused about that part. I'm not sure if I should be talking about that with a psychiatrist, though. Maybe I shouldn't be telling anyone about that. What about masturbation, is that a problem too?"

But that doesn't matter to most people. Some would rather stay in the Matrix than be arrested for being criminals. "No, I'm not a criminal," I reply.

I was the only one who knew where to look for her.
